Posts.Content: Aug 19, 2011 05:40PM - edited Aug 19, 2011 05:45PM by jyg Your mammogram alone is probably enough to disqualify you from being a kidney donor. If you are otherwise eligible and want to donate, you just might need a biopsy to "prove" no malignancy with BI-RADS 4. There are sub-categories (A,B,C) that can help with the prediction of breast cancer. But no radiologist will give you a diagnosis. That being said... Sitting down with the radiologist to see the calcifications (and believe me, they are micro) you might be astonished at how small something can be and still be suspicious for breast cancer, be it DCIS or even IDC. This would also give you a chance to discuss how "suspicious" the lesion is. Breast cancer cannot be diagnosed by x-ray findings alone - only by tissue sample. How you choose to treat the results (if not benign) are completely up to you. Jan
Posts.Title: B4 Bi-Rad Category 4 soma4 SJW1

Posts.Content: Aug 20, 2011 06:58PM jyg wrote: soma - I would really sit down with the radiologist and find out just how worrisome the calcifications are. BI-RADS 4 subcategory C can have 95% probablity of cancer, whereas A only has 2%. Waiting another 3-6 months - I would not do that without a discussion with a radiologist who reads mammograms all the time. (And, I didn't suggest that.) The natural history of DCIS is not known. You might have this (Stage 0) or just fibrocystic disease that has some calcifications or something worse. DCIS can progress or it can sit there for years without changing - there is not enough scientific data (in fact really no studies) to say which lesions progress and which do not. But first one has to know that there is something to worry about. A stereotactic biopsy is not that big of a deal (a least mine were not - just ended up with bruising, no pain). This is just my 2 cents worth. Lots of options but best to find out what they are from an expert skilled in reading mammograms. Jan
Posts.Title: B4 Bi-Rad Category 4 soma4 SJW1

Posts.Content: Sep 21, 2011 08:09AM jyg wrote: I am so sorry you are having to start on a journey no one wants take, which is being in limbo about potential breast cancer and waiting. Thank goodness they were able to get you in for a mammo and to see a surgeon so quickly. A diagnosis cannot be made without tissue, so try not to get ahead in your thinking. (Ignore everything the med student said except for any words of comfort. They don't know enough to give advice about treatment, especially when you do not have a diagnosis.) Stick around for support. Ask questions. Keep us up to date. Try to keep on your normal routine or other activities that you find grounding in times of stress. Be sure to sleep. We are all for each other as much as we are to get info and receive support ourselves. Jan

Posts.Content: Jul 1, 2011 02:37PM jyg wrote: theatercat - Even if your chest wall is numb, be sure she numbs up your skin just to be sure she doesn't hit an area that is unexpectedly sensitive. Usually drainage is just done with a needle and large syringe. Draining will be a relief. If you have as large an infected area as you describe, don't be surprised if you do get a brief admission for antibiotics. Do you have TEs or some other type of reconstructive surgery going on? I had a seroma drained Tuesday, and it did not hurt at all, but today the amount feels just a big as before. Going back tomorrow for TE expansion & probably another aspiration

Posts.Content: Jun 20, 2011 01:56PM jyg wrote: If you aren't allergic to Chloraprep, the benefit to leaving it on is that it provides antibacterial action for up to 48 hours. (Assuming all the gore is washed off!) I was concerned after BMX to find orange skin since I am so allergic to iodine then found out that Chloraprep had been formulated to be that color so the OR staff could tell where they had prepped the patient.
Posts.Title: itching from chloraprep surgical scrub vlnrph mortmain

Posts.Content: Aug 18, 2011 10:11PM jyg wrote: Never ignore blood in your stool, although hemorrhoids are the most common cause. Infections, reactions to antibiotics or other meds, a bleeding tumor (not always cancer), tears alon the anal lining can all cause bright red blood like you are describing. The point is to have this evaluated. Your primary care doc can start the work up tomorrow (unless the bleeding continues profusely tonight)
